Award.AwardTitle: iCREAT: A pathway to middle-skill positions through the Introduction to Coding, Robotics, Electronics, And Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project at Massachusetts Bay Community College (MBCC) establishes a STEM pathway towards middle-skill careers in electronics and associated technology. The plan starts by targeting high school students during the junior year and provides a program leading to certification and/or associates degrees. This project aims to address state of Massachusetts and national workforce needs for trained technicians. The program therefore engages high school-aged youth and community college students in learning electronics, coding, and engineering design and manufacturing through an interdisciplinary project-based approach that serves as a launching point along technical career pathways such as information technology technical hardware support, computer numerical control (CNC) operation, computer aided design and manufacturing (CAD/CAM), and others. The project is designed to broaden participation by recruiting, retaining, and preparing students from underrepresented populations in STEM. To attract and engage students, the project is creating a year-long course sequence co-taught by MBCC STEM faculty from multiple departments. The courses are designed to mirror learning and work in the workplace by engaging students in applying critical thinking skills and leveraging technical knowledge and skills from many content areas. The courses, available for college credit for high school students in the junior to senior years, allow the students to get a head start on post-secondary education and retain admitted MBCC students in STEM fields. Partnerships with local organizations and industry will help provide career guidance and find internship opportunities for students. A web-based mentoring program will aid retention by connecting participants with STEM professionals.

The project has a research goal to provide the community with an evidence-based model around how program components support or do not support students to pursue a STEM career pathway. The study focuses on the role of intentionality and adaptability as optimal outcomes of engaging in STEM education. Using an expanded version of Navarro's (et alia, 2007) Math/Science Intentions and Goals Scale and Savickas' & Porfeli's (2012) Career Adapt-Abilities Scale, the project is studying 1) intention, referring to "orientation toward action," by examining intentions to pursue a STEM career pathway and to actively consider STEM careers and 2) career adaptability which is a psychosocial construct denoting an individual's resources of self-regulation or capacity for coping with tasks, transitions, and traumas in occupational roles. A key hypothesis is that the interventions will enhance individuals' skills for self-regulation and will develop their capacity to internalize these skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The iCREAT project is successfully completed and the outcomes are:

Interdisciplinary courses to encourage youth to STEM fields and careers

The MassBay Community College team developed two interdisciplinary college level course curricula (iCREAT I and iCREAT II). Both courses are highly hands-on and project-based. They instill computational thinking, problem solving, engineering, and system design while promoting active learning and team collaboration.

The iCREAT I course covers the basics of electronics, coding, robotics, system design process, computer aided design and manufacturing (CAD/CAM) and additive manufacturing (3D printing); knowledge and skills that are required to create a micro-mouse-like robot. Mentoring and career planning modules are also integrated into the course.

The iCREAT II course covers topics that are required to create a Telepresence robot. This includes Python programming, Linux Operating System, networking & communication, security, and subtractive manufacturing (CNC).

The majority (87.25%) of iCREAT I students successfully completed the class and received 3 college credits. The fact that all (100%) iCREAT II students successfully completed the course is a testament to the high level of knowledge and skills gained in the iCREAT I course. This is also evident from the overall (both courses for 3 years) students’ success rate of 85.87%. Almost 40% of iCREAT I students came back the next summer to take iCREAT II.

According to the project’s external evaluator, students indicated that “the course helped increase or solidify their interest in a STEM pathway, including clarifying or reinforcing their interest in a specific field or topic.”

Research on STEM career development

The Boston College (BC) team developed the career exploration and development education piece of the iCREAT project while conducting research on the project (course, mentoring, and career development). BC’s Co-PIs and graduate students created and conducted the pre and post questionnaires and student interviews.

iCREAT students were taught about the career development process and the growth and exploration processes that are most relevant to students. Students took a career assessment that provides information about their personality profiles and related potential job opportunities.
Students learned about barriers that could interfere with their desired careers and the steps they could take, such as connecting with mentors or support groups, to buffer against or cope with any perceived challenges.

Web -based mentoring

In year 1, the MentorNet team provisioned an instance of their Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) platform for the iCREAT students only. Non-STEM graduate students from Boston College, who had mentoring experience were recruited as mentors. Students reported unease when talking to their mentors virtually.

In year 2, the meeting topics were revised to align them with course content and recruitment focused on near-peer mentors who had STEM background. However, community college alums (near-peer) were not accessible. Several local mentors were recruited to allow for at least one in-person meeting. Students reported mixed success as some of them could not meet in person, due to mentor’s job constraints.

Year 3 experienced use of different technology (Zoom and SMS proxy). The logistics (laptops with installed and registered software, earbuds, TAs to help with issues) were managed, but students felt the relationship was forced. Although course topics were shared with mentors; mentors and students felt that they didn’t see a connection between the course and mentoring topics.

In general, high school students did not seem so keen on meeting with strangers, who were matched for them, and did not show enthusiasm for mentoring.

Impacts

Underrepresented students – iCREAT high school students were diverse in terms of gender, racial (and bi-racial) background, first to go to college in their family, financial status, and language spoken at home. Tuition was waived for 20% of students who could not afford the already reduced tuition of $100.

Pathway – high school students who completed the iCREAT I course earned 3 college credits at MassBay, which can be transferred to UMass Lowell or Wentworth Technical Institute.

Teaching Assistant (TA) – 17 MassBay students were trained to assist in the iCREAT classes by learning and completing course assignments. All TAs, regardless of their academic major, were trained to know all topics of the course they were assisting. TA’s were able to add valuable skills to their resumes.

Team-teaching model – the multidisciplinary nature of the iCREAT courses offered faculty the chance to learn about other disciplines leading to a more streamlined curriculum content and more efficient student learning outcomes. This experience can become a role model for future interdisciplinary courses involving STEM and non-STEM faculty.

Adoption of curricula – the iCREAT I course was offered to high school teachers, which prepared them to adopt the course at their school.

The iCREAT web site (http://massbay.edu/icreat) is available to the public and allows interested parties to request access to the curriculum.
